title: 109_hr4867
content: The "Puerto Rico Democracy Act of 2006" includes provisions for a federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, initial plebiscite, subsequent procedures, applicable laws, and availability of funds. The Congress acknowledges past efforts by Presidents Bush and Clinton to address Puerto Rico's political status through referendums and task forces. President George W. Bush established the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status to identify options for the territory's political future that align with US laws. Executive Order 13183 required regular reports on progress towards determining Puerto Rico's ultimate status. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status, established by President George W. Bush, recommended a federally sanctioned plebiscite for Puerto Ricans to vote on their territorial status or pursue a nonterritorial status. If the people of Puerto Rico elect a permanent nonterritorial status, Congress should hold a plebiscite for them to choose between two options. Once a majority selects an option, Congress should start transitioning towards it. If Puerto Rico chooses to remain a US territory, periodic plebiscites should be held to keep Congress informed of the people's wishes. Federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite in Puerto Rico to choose between continuing the existing territorial status or pursuing a path towards a permanent nonterritorial status. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct plebiscites every 8 years if the majority vote favors the existing territorial status. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct plebiscites every 8 years unless a majority vote favors permanent nonterritorial status, in which case a new plebiscite will be held with only two options: statehood or nonterritorial status. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct plebiscites every 8 years with two options for voters to choose from: statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. Voters must mark their choice on the ballot. If a majority vote favors permanent nonterritorial status in the plebiscite, another plebiscite will be held within 2 years. If the plebiscite in subsection (b) results in a majority vote for permanent nonterritorial status, another plebiscite must be held within 2 years. SEC. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS. All Federal laws applicable to the election of the Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico also apply to any plebiscite held under this Act. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over legal claims related to this Act. Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will issue necessary rules and regulations. Controversies may arise from the implementation of the Act. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will issue rules and regulations for plebiscites. Eligibility to vote includes all eligible voters under Puerto Rico's electoral laws and US citizens born in Puerto Rico who meet the Commission's requirements. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will certify the results of each plebiscite held under this Act to the President of the United States and the Senate. Eligible voters can request an absentee ballot for the plebiscite. The Elections Commission will certify plebiscite results to the President and Congress. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status will submit a report detailing measures for the chosen nonterritorial status option. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status will submit a report detailing measures for the chosen nonterritorial status option, along with recommendations deemed appropriate. SEC. 5. AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS FOR THE SELF-DETERMINATION PROCESS. During the period from October 1, 2006, until all plebiscites required by this Act are completed, the Secretary of the Treasury can allocate up to $5,000,000 from funds provided to Puerto Rico for election expenses, including voter education materials approved by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status may identify necessary amounts for purposes not incompatible with the Constitution and laws of the United States.
